newsitem.title: GREECE: ATHLETICS-BOLDON SETS SIGHTS ON WORLD 100 METRES RECORD.
newsitem.headline: ATHLETICS-BOLDON SETS SIGHTS ON WORLD 100 METRES RECORD.

text.p: Ato Boldon, the world 200 metres gold medal firmly in his grasp, now plans to attack Donovan Bailey's world 100 record.
Boldon won the 200 title on Friday evening after finishing fifth behind training partner Maurice Greene of the United States in the 100 metres last Sunday.
"I was supposed to win both races," Boldon said on Saturday. "I was reminded of a lesson and that is that the public does not care why you didn't win.
"Wether you like it or not, the 100 metres is the most prestigious event. I wasn't able to win that one but I decided to go for the 200 and give my all."
"I just hit that gun, then my 15 first steps were awesome.
"I took a quick glance to my right and saw nobody there. I was shocked and happy at the same time. And relieved."
Boldon, who finished third in both the 100 and 200 metres at last year's Atlanta Olympics, now plans to reduce Bailey's mark of 9.84 set in the Olympic final.
"It can definitely fall," said Boldon. "It is very approachable and the fact that everybody is coming close says just that."
Asked when the record would come and who would break it, Boldon said Bailey, Greene and himself stood a chance in the remaining European Grands Prix.
He said the Zurich and Brussels Golden Four meetings were the most likely venues.

"It can happen everywhere but I would personally like to reward them (the organisers of Zurich and Brussels) with a world record in their meeting," Boldon said. "I'll give my best effort and my best effort can be very dangerous in terms of approaching or breaking the world record."
Boldon, who moved to the United States when he was 14, said he was proud to have given Trinidad and Tobago their first world title.

"Before the start of the race, I saw myself on the screen and I just touched the colours on my chest," he said. "When an American sprinter wins, the impact is not that great. With me, it's different. The kids back home expect me to win. If I don't, they will have a bad day."
